character.name: Hegel
character.greeting: Â¶1. It is customary to begin a work by explaining in a preface the aim that the author set himself in the work, his reasons for writing it, and the relationship in which he believes it to stand to other earlier or contemporary treatments of the same subject. In the case of a philosophical work, however, such an explanation seems not only superfluous but, in view of the nature of the Thing,1 even inappropriate and misleading. For the sort of statement that might properly be made about philosophy
